snippet: Lawyers for Cecil Clayton, who lost 7.7 percent of his brain in a sawmill accident, say his life should be spared because he cannot grasp the significance of his death sentence.
abstract: Lawyers for Cecil Clayton, who murdered Missouri Police Officer Christopher L Castetter in 1996, are trying to avert his death penalty sentence by arguing that Clayton is too mentally impaired to understand significance of his crime or penalty; Clayton suffered severe head injury in 1972 that led to loss of 20 percent of his frontal lobe; case reflects ongoing debate over mentally ill or impaired people who commit crimes.
lead_paragraph: Lawyers for Cecil Clayton, who lost 7.7 percent of his brain in a sawmill accident, say his life should be spared because he cannot grasp the significance of his death sentence.

headline.main: Lawyers Seek Reprieve for Killer Who Lost Part of His Brain Decades Earlier
